title: 108_hr1469
content: The Act titled "Women's Obstetrician and Gynecologist Access Now Act" aims to improve women's access to obstetrical and gynecological services through amendments to the Public Health Service Act. The "Women's Obstetrician and Gynecologist Access Now Act" ensures that group health plans and insurance issuers allow direct access to obstetrical and gynecological services without requiring prior approval from other providers. The "Women's Obstetrician and Gynecologist Access Now Act" allows plans and issuers to establish communication requirements between obstetricians, gynecologists, and primary care physicians. It also permits the establishment of utilization protocols for these healthcare providers within the network. The "Women's Obstetrician and Gynecologist Access Now Act" permits group health plans to establish communication requirements and utilization protocols for obstetricians, gynecologists, and primary care physicians, ensuring that the requirements are consistent with other physicians, not more restrictive for obstetrical and gynecological services, and compliant with ERISA notice requirements. ERISA amendments include adding a new section to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. SEC. 714. STANDARD RELATING TO WOMEN'S ACCESS TO OBSTETRICAL AND GYNECOLOGICAL SERVICES. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must allow participants to seek obstetrical and gynecological services directly from designated physicians without requiring prior approval from other providers or the plan. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must allow participants to seek obstetrical and gynecological services directly from designated physicians without prior approval. Plans can establish reasonable requirements for communication between physicians and utilization protocols for participating providers. Physicians and surgeons in group health plans must be allowed to provide obstetrical and gynecological services without prior approval, as long as the requirements are consistent with those for other physicians, and not more restrictive. The imposition of this requirement is considered a material modification. The requirement for physicians and surgeons in group health plans to provide obstetrical and gynecological services without prior approval is considered a material modification. Section 732(a) of the Act is amended to include sections 711 and 714. The table of contents in section 1 of the Act is also amended to include a new item after section 713. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new standard relating to women's access to obstetrical and gynecological services. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new standard allowing direct access to obstetrical and gynecological physician services for participants and beneficiaries of group health plans and insurance issuers. Prior approval from other physicians or providers is not required for this direct access. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow direct access to obstetrician and gynecologist or family practice physician services for participants and beneficiaries of group health plans and insurance issuers without the need for prior approval from other physicians. The plan or issuer can establish reasonable requirements for communication between physicians and provisions for utilization protocols, as long as they are consistent with the intent of the subsection and customary for other physicians. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow direct access to obstetrician and gynecologist or family practice physician services for participants and beneficiaries of group health plans and insurance issuers without the need for prior approval from other physicians. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to Section 4980D(d)(1) of the Code. SEC. 2753. Standard for women's access to obstetrical and gynecological services. The provisions of section 2707(a) apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market as they do in connection with a group health plan. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to those under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Effective dates for group health plans and insurance coverage are specified. The amendment made by subsection (b) applies to individual health insurance coverage in the market on or after the enactment date. There is an exception for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment date. The Secretary of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services must coordinate administration through an interagency memorandum of understanding to ensure regulations are consistent. Plan amendments made under a collective bargaining agreement to comply with new requirements are not considered termination of the agreement. The Secretaries must coordinate to ensure consistent administration and enforcement of regulations to avoid duplication of efforts and assign enforcement priorities.
